No!  Never put a key decision maker at the table until you are ready to close the deal.  The problem is that it gives the other side an wash opportunity to corner the decision maker on key issue.  Also it limits the ability of the team to sound out options without having to commit.   You need the ability to say yes but wr can't commit that until we check.

author: Matthew Brower
text: City Managers play important roles in union relationships and negotiating collective bargaining agreements.  The questions is whether City Managers should be active participants at the collective bargaining table, or leave this duty to their designated bargaining team?
title: Union Negotiations and the City Manager
